abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Jaiba Irrigation
            Project is rated as satisfactory, sustainability as likely,
            institutional development impact as substantial, bank
            performance as satisfactory, and borrower performance as
            satisfactory. The project provides various lessons: 1) The
            project financing plan should carefully evaluate the
            government's ability to meet counterpart funding
            requirements, and macroeconomic factors and conditions must
            be taken into consideration during preparation. 2) External
            financing usually pays more attention to infrastructure and
            environmental mitigation over agricultural development. 3)
            Delays in project implementation could have been avoided or
            shortened. 4) Risks should be properly identified, and
            mitigating measures adopted. 5) An independent and
            self-sustaining entity for project administration, operation
            and maintenance is essential to ensure long-term
            sustainability. 6) Good baseline data and an early
            implementation of effective monitoring system are essential.
            7) Successful diversification of crop production depends on
            obtaining small farmers' confidence. 8) Agricultural
            credits are always a decisive factor in becoming a
            successful farmer. 9) Selection of beneficiaries in an
            important element in assuring long-term sustainability. 10)
            It is important to maintain a well-balanced mix of
            small/medium farmers as beneficiaries to maximize the
            development impact. 11) Rules should be thoroughly thought
            out and then applied.
